Towards Communication-efficient Federated Learning via Sparse and Aligned Adaptive Optimization

Xiumei Deng, Jun Li, Kang Wei, Long Shi, Zeihui Xiong, Ming Ding, Wen Chen, Shi Jin, and H. Vincent Poor X. Deng, J. Li and L. Abstract

Adaptive moment estimation (Adam), as a Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) variant, has gained widespread popularity in federated learning (FL) due to its fast convergence. However, federated Adam (FedAdam) algorithms suffer from a threefold increase in uplink communication overhead compared to federated SGD (FedSGD) algorithms, which arises from the necessity to transmit both local model updates and first and second moment estimates from distributed devices to the centralized server for aggregation. Driven by this issue, we propose a novel sparse FedAdam algorithm called FedAdam-SSM, wherein distributed devices sparsify the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates and subsequently upload the sparse representations to the centralized server. To further reduce the communication overhead, the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates incorporate a shared sparse mask (SSM) into the sparsification process, eliminating the need for three separate sparse masks. Theoretically, we develop an upper bound on the divergence between the local model trained by FedAdam-SSM and the desired model trained by centralized Adam, which is related to sparsification error and imbalanced data distribution. By minimizing the divergence bound between the model trained by FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam, we optimize the SSM to mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by sparsification error. Additionally, we provide convergence bounds for FedAdam-SSM in both convex and non-convex objective function settings, and investigate the impact of local epoch, learning rate and sparsification ratio on the convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM. Experimental results show that FedAdam-SSM outperforms baselines in terms of convergence rate (over 1.1×\times faster than the sparse FedAdam baselines) and test accuracy (over 14.5% ahead of the quantized FedAdam baselines).

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Adam Optimizer, Sparsification method.

I Introduction

Recent advances in Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies have empowered next-generation smart devices to bring us higher levels of comfort, convenience, connectivity, and intelligence[1, 2, 3]. The explosion of IoT data, limited data transmission capacity, as well as potential data privacy and security threats, make it impractical to upload all the raw data to a remote cloud for centralized machine learning (ML)[4, 5]. To avoid collecting private data from distributed devices, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a privacy-enhancing distributed ML paradigm[6, 7, 8], where distributed devices perform local model training on their private datasets, and a centralized server aggregates the uploaded local models to build a global model.

In recent years, the size of ML models has dramatically increased to achieve high accuracy and adapt to dynamic environments in many application scenarios such as computer vision, natural language processing and speech recognition[9, 10]. In practice, ML models, especially deep learning models, are typically hundreds of megabytes or even gigabytes in size. As the size of state-of-the-art ML models continues to explode, the implementation of an efficient FL paradigm faces the following challenges. 1) Convergence speed. Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) has been widely applied to FL training. Despite its simplicity, the vanilla SGD suffers from slow convergence, and is sensitive to variations in hyper-parameters (e.g., learning rate). To reduce the computational burden on distributed devices throughout the FL training process, it is paramount to deploy advanced optimizers to improve the convergence rate while maintaining model accuracy. 2) Communication overhead. Since distributed devices in FL frequently upload/download ML models to/from the centralized server, large-scale ML models inevitably lead to unaffordable communication overhead. Especially in wireless networks, high traffic between distributed devices and the centralized server can overwhelm the limited transmission bandwidth, resulting in frequent interruptions, prolonged latencies and prohibitive costs.

As a variant of SGD, adaptive moment estimation (Adam) has gained widespread popularity in FL due to its fast convergence and intuitive explanations behind the adaptive hyper-parameters[11, 12]. However, federated Adam (FedAdam for short) algorithms suffer from a threefold increase in uplink communication overhead compared to federated SGD (FedSGD for short) algorithms, which arises from the necessity to transmit both local model updates and first and second moment estimates (i.e., exponential moving averages of historical gradients and gradient squares) from distributed devices to the centralized server for aggregation. Despite current efforts to enhance the convergence rate of FedAdam algorithms, how to reduce this communication overhead remains open in the literature. Driven by this issue, we propose a novel sparsification method for communication-efficient FedAdam. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    FedAdam-SSM. We propose a sparse FedAdam algorithm called FedAdam-SSM, wherein distributed devices sparsify the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates and subsequently upload the sparse representations to the centralized server. To further reduce the communication overhead, the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates incorporate a shared sparse mask (SSM) into the sparsification process, eliminating the need for three separate sparse masks. Compared with the standard FedAdam, FedAdam-SSM effectively reduces the uplink communication overhead from 𝒪​(3​d​q)𝒪3𝑑𝑞\mathcal{O}(3dq) to 𝒪​(3​k​q+d)𝒪3𝑘𝑞𝑑\mathcal{O}(3kq+d).

  2. 2.

    Shared sparse mask design. We optimize the SSM to mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by the sparsification error. Firstly, we provide an upper bound on the divergence between the local model trained by FedAdam-SSM and the desired model trained by centralized Adam. To minimize the sparsification error of FedAdam-SSM, we devise an optimal SSM by minimizing the divergence bound between FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam.

  3. 3.

    Convergence analysis. We provide convergence bounds for FedAdam-SSM in both non-convex and convex objective function settings. We prove that the convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM achieves a linear speedup of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}) in the non-convex setting, and can be further increased to 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{T}) in the convex setting. Additionally, we investigate the impact of local epoch, learning rate and sparsification ratio on the convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM, and provides guidance for selecting appropriate values of local epoch and learning rate to improve the learning performance of FedAdam-SSM.

  4. 4.

    Experimental results. We conduct extensive experiments involving training of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Visual Geometry Group-11 (VGG-11) and Residual Network-18 (ResNet-18) over Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10 and SVHN datasets to investigate the training performance of the proposed FedAdam-SSM. The experimental results verify our theoretical analysis and show that FedAdam-SSM outperforms baselines in terms of convergence rate (over 1.1×\times faster than the best sparse FedAdam baseline) and test accuracy (over 14.5% ahead of the best quantized FedAdam baseline).

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II discusses related works. Section III briefly provides some background on FL, FedAdam and the sparsification methods. In Section IV, we propose the FedAdam-SSM algorithm. In Section V, we optimize the SSM to mitigate the sparsification error. Section VI conducts the convergence analysis, and Section VII represents the experimental results. Section VIII concludes this paper.

II Significance and Related Work

In this section, we review two lines of work that are most related to this paper, i.e., SGD variants in FL and communication-efficient FL.

II-A SGD variants in FL

The low convergence rate and the considerable effort required to find the optimal hyper-parameters of vanilla SGD can place a significant burden on the computational capacity of distributed devices, leading to long FL training sessions and unsatisfactory quality of experience. To accelerate the model convergence, recent works have developed a variety of SGD variants in the FL setting. The authors in [13] and [14] propose a Nesterov Accelerated Gradient Descent (NAG) based FL framework named FedNAG to speed up FL convergence, where distributed devices locally update the model parameters and first momentum estimates, and upload the local model parameters and momentum estimates to the centralized server for aggregation. The convergence analysis presented in [13] reveals that FedNAG can converge faster than FedSGD. Using the variance-reduced SGD (SVRG) optimizer, the works in [15] and [16] improve the FL convergence rate by gradually eliminating the inherent variance of the gradients. Later on, by adaptively tuning the learning rate with both the first momentum estimate and the second momentum estimate, the works in [17, 18, 19] develop different FedAdam algorithms to accelerate the training process, and prove the convergence of the proposed algorithms for both convex and non-convex settings.

From the above, the integration of SGD variants into FL has proven to improve the convergence rate in the training process, especially for Adam. FedAdam algorithms not only have well-documented empirical performance, but can also be shown theoretically to escape saddle points and converge to second-order stationary points faster than FedSGD. On the one hand, FedAdam accelerates the FL convergence thanks to the adaptive learning rate tuned by the first and second momentum estimates. On the other hand, the first and second momentum estimates have to be uploaded to the centralized server for aggregation, which significantly increases the uplink communication overhead. To this end, strategies to reduce the communication overhead are of considerable importance in improving the training efficiency of FedAdam.

II-B Communication-efficient Federated Learning

In order to achieve communication-efficient FL, different methods to reduce the communication overhead have been proposed in the literature. Early works have considered device scheduling and communication resource allocation. The authors in [20] and [21] optimize the device selection as well as communication and computational resource allocation to minimize the training latency while guaranteeing FL performance. However, when dealing with large-scale ML models and limited communication resources, device scheduling and communication resource allocation alone to reduce communication overhead may prove insufficient in achieving the desired training efficiency.

More recently, compression techniques such as quantization and sparsification methods have been introduced into FL to reduce the size of local model updates transmitted to the centralized server. The authors in [22, 23, 24, 25, 26] develop different quantization or sparsifation strategies, which adaptively tune the quantization level or sparsifation ratio to reduce the communication overhead while guaranteeing a low compression error. Going forward, the implementation of compression methods in FedAdam algorithms remains challenging. The authors in [27] and [28] propose two different communication-efficient FedAdam algorithms, which quantize local model updates or model parameters to reduce the communication cost, and compensate for the quantization errors using an error-feedback technique. To further improve the model accuracy, [29] proposes a 2-phase FedAdam algorithm, which runs the standard FedAdam in the warm-up phase, and computes the second moment estimates as a fixed precondition for the quantized FedAdam in the compression phase.

However, the works in [27, 28, 29] set the number of local epochs to 1, which results in extremely frequent communication between distributed devices and the centralized server and thereby increases both the compression error and the communication overhead in FedAdam. Moreover, these works fail to consider the aggregation of the first and second local momentum estimates to obtain global momentum estimates in each communication round, which results in the utilization of out-of-date momentum estimates in the training process and consequently causes a degradation in FL performance. Subsequently, [30] adopts two different quantization methods (i.e., uniform and exponential quantization methods) to quantize the local model updates and the momentum estimates in the proposed FedAdam algorithm. However, due to the fact that Adam depends non-linearly on the gradient, the authors do not provide a convergence analysis of quantized FedAdam.

In our work, we integrate the sparsification method with the standard FedAdam. Different from the aforementioned works on communication-efficient FedAdam [29, 28, 30], we take into account the up-to-date global momentum estimates by sparsifying the updates of local model parameters and momentum estimates before uploading them to the centralized server in each communication round. To further alleviate the communication overhead, we incorporate a shared sparse mask into the sparsification of the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates. To mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by the sparsification error, we optimize the shared sparse mask by minimizing the divergence bound between the local model trained by FedAdam-SSM and the desired model trained by centralized Adam. To the best of our knowledge, our work represents the first attempt to design a shared sparse mask for the sparsification of the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates in sparse FedAdam and to provide a theoretical analysis of this approach.

III Preliminaries and Background

In this section, we overview a few important concepts and definitions with regard to FedAdam and sparsification method.

III-A FedAdam

Consider an FL network of N𝑁N devices collaborating to train an ML model over their respective local datasets. Let 𝒩={1,2,…,N}𝒩12…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,...,N\} denote the index set of the devices. The goal of FL is to find a set of model parameters 𝒘∗∈ℝdsuperscript𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} that minimizes the global loss function F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F(\boldsymbol{w}) on all the local datasets, i.e.,

F​(𝒘)=∑n=1N|𝒟n|​f​(𝒘,𝒟n)∑n=1N|𝒟n|,𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑛𝑓𝒘subscript𝒟𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑛\displaystyle F(\boldsymbol{w})=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n})}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{n}|}, (1)

where f​(𝒘,𝒟n)𝑓𝒘subscript𝒟𝑛f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n}) denotes the loss function on the local dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n}. In standard FedSGD, distributed devices utilize SGD to minimize the local loss function Fn​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑛𝒘F_{n}(\boldsymbol{w}) on its local dataset by updating the local model parameters over a total of L𝐿L local epochs. The update rule in the l𝑙l-th local epoch is

𝒘nl+1,t=𝒘nl,t−η​∇f​(𝒘nl,t,𝒟~n),superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡𝜂∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡subscript~𝒟𝑛\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l+1,t}=\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t}-\eta\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}), (2)

where 𝒘nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t} denotes the local model parameters of the n𝑛n-th device in the l𝑙l-th local epoch and t𝑡t-th communication round, η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is the learning rate, ∇f​(𝒘nl,t,𝒟~n)∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡subscript~𝒟𝑛\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}) is the mini-batch stochastic gradient of the local loss function, and 𝒟~nsubscript~𝒟𝑛\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n} is a batch of the local dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n}.

To improve the accuracy of the ML model and accelerate the training process, Adam was proposed as a variant of SGD by taking into consideration momentum and root mean square propagation[27, 28, 29]. To be specific, it takes advantage of momentum by moving in the negative direction of the first moment estimate of the gradient, and maintains a per-parameter learning rate adjusted to the second moment estimate of the gradient. Using Adam, the local model update rule in FL training can be written as

𝒘nl,t=𝒘nl−1,t−η​𝒎nl,t𝒗nl,t+ϵ,superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙1𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝑙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝑙𝑡italic-ϵ\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t}=\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l-1,t}-\eta\frac{\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{l,t}}{\sqrt{\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{l,t}+\epsilon}}, (3)

where 𝒎nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{l,t} and 𝒗nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{l,t} are the first and second moment estimates of the gradient, and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is a safety offset for division by the second moment estimate. Specifically, the first and second moment estimates 𝒎nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{l,t} and 𝒗nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{l,t} are computed as

𝒎nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝑙𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{l,t} =β1​𝒎nl−1,t+(1−β1)​∇f​(𝒘nl−1,t,𝒟~n),absentsubscript𝛽1superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝑙1𝑡1subscript𝛽1∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙1𝑡subscript~𝒟𝑛\displaystyle=\beta_{1}\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{l-1,t}+(1-\beta_{1})\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l-1,t},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}), (4)
𝒗nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝑙𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{l,t} =β2​𝒗nl−1,t+(1−β2)​(∇f​(𝒘nl−1,t,𝒟~n))2,absentsubscript𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝑙1𝑡1subscript𝛽2superscript∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙1𝑡subscript~𝒟𝑛2\displaystyle=\beta_{2}\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{l-1,t}+(1-\beta_{2})\left(\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l-1,t},\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n})\right)^{2}, (5)

where β1∈[0,1)subscript𝛽101\beta_{1}\in[0,1) and β2∈[0,1)subscript𝛽201\beta_{2}\in[0,1) control the exponential decay rates of the moving averages. Therefore, the procedure of FedAdam in each communication round is as follows:

  1. 1.

    According to the update rule in (3), (4), and (5), each device updates the local moment estimates and model parameters (i.e., 𝒎nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{l,t}, 𝒗nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{l,t}, and 𝒘nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t}) over a total of L𝐿L local epochs at the beginning of each round.

  2. 2.

    Each device uploads the updated local moment estimates and model parameters (i.e., 𝒎nL,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝐿𝑡\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{L,t}, 𝒗nL,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝐿𝑡\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{L,t}, and 𝒘nL,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝐿𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{L,t}) to the centralized server.

  3. 3.

    Upon receiving all the local moment estimates and local model parameters, the centralized server updates the global moment estimates and model parameters according to the federated averaging (FedAvg) algorithm, i.e., 𝑴t+1=∑n=1N|𝒟~n|​𝒎nL,t∑n=1N|𝒟~n|superscript𝑴𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝐿𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛\boldsymbol{M}^{t+1}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{L,t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|}, 𝑽t+1=∑n=1N|𝒟~n|​𝒗nL,t∑n=1N|𝒟~n|superscript𝑽𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝐿𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛\boldsymbol{V}^{t+1}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{L,t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|}, and 𝑾t+1=∑n=1N|𝒟~n|​𝒘nL,t∑n=1N|𝒟~n|superscript𝑾𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝐿𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛\boldsymbol{W}^{t+1}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{L,t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|}.

  4. 4.

    Each device downloads the updated global moment estimates and model parameters from the centralized server for the next communication round of FedAdam.

III-B Sparsification Method

To reduce the communication overhead, sparsification methods have been extensively studied in FL to convert the local model parameters or accumulated gradients into a sparse representation before they are transmitted from distributed devices to the centralized server. Specifically, each device in FL induces a sparse mask on the d𝑑d-dimensional vector to map each element of the vector to either its original value or zero, and transmit the values of the non-zero elements and the sparse mask to the centralized server. The top-k𝑘k sparsifier used in this paper is defined as follows:

Definition 1

(Top-k𝑘k sparsifier). For any positive integer 1≤k≤d1𝑘𝑑1\leq k\leq d and any vector 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the top-k𝑘k sparsifier TopksubscriptTop𝑘\text{Top}_{k}: ℝd→ℝd→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is defined as

Topk​(𝒙)≔𝒙⊙𝟙Topk​(𝒙),≔subscriptTop𝑘𝒙direct-product𝒙subscript1subscriptTop𝑘𝒙\text{Top}_{k}(\boldsymbol{x})\coloneqq\boldsymbol{x}\odot\mathbbm{1}_{\text{Top}_{k}}(\boldsymbol{x}), (6)

where 𝟙Topk​(𝐱)∈{0,1}dsubscript1subscriptTop𝑘𝐱superscript01𝑑\mathbbm{1}_{\text{Top}_{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})\in\{0,1\}^{d} represents the sparse mask of TopksubscriptTop𝑘\text{Top}_{k}, and ⊙direct-product\odot performs the element-wise product. The sparse mask of TopksubscriptTop𝑘\text{Top}_{k} is defined as

(𝟙Topk​(𝒙))π​(j)≔{1,if​j≤k,0,otherwise,≔subscriptsubscript1subscriptTop𝑘𝒙𝜋𝑗cases1if𝑗𝑘0otherwise\left(\mathbbm{1}_{\text{Top}_{k}}(\boldsymbol{x})\right)_{\pi(j)}\coloneqq\begin{cases}1,&\mbox{if}~{}j\leq k,\\ 0,&\mbox{otherwise},\end{cases} (7)

where π𝜋\pi is a permutation of [d]delimited-[]𝑑\left[d\right] such that |(𝐱)π​(j)|≥|(𝐱)π​(j+1)|subscript𝐱𝜋𝑗subscript𝐱𝜋𝑗1|\left(\boldsymbol{x}\right)_{\pi(j)}|\geq|\left(\boldsymbol{x}\right)_{\pi(j+1)}| for j∈[1,d−1]𝑗1𝑑1j\in[1,d-1].

It is clear to see that the top-k𝑘k sparsifier selects the top k𝑘k largest elements in terms of the absolute value. In addition, the top-k𝑘k sparsifier satisfies the k𝑘k-contraction property[31, 32] as follows:

Definition 2

(k𝑘k-contraction property). For a positive integer 1≤k≤d1𝑘𝑑1\leq k\leq d and any vector 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, a k𝑘k-contraction operator Comp: ℝd→ℝd→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfies the contraction property:

𝔼​[‖𝒙−Comp​(𝒙)‖2]≤(1−kd)​‖𝒙‖2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒙Comp𝒙21𝑘𝑑superscriptnorm𝒙2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\boldsymbol{x}-\text{Comp}(\boldsymbol{x})\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\left(1-\frac{k}{d}\right)\left\|\boldsymbol{x}\right\|^{2}. (8)

Notably, the sparsification ratio is defined as the ratio of originally-valued elements over all elements, i.e.,

α=kd.𝛼𝑘𝑑\alpha=\frac{k}{d}. (9)

IV FedAdam-SSM

In this section, we first present a straightforward sparse FedAdam algorithm called FedAdam-Top, which separately sparsifies the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates with the top-k𝑘k sparsifier. Building upon FedAdam-Top, we propose FedAdam-SSM, which incorporates an SSM into the sparsification of the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates to further reduce the uplink communication overhead.

Using the top-k𝑘k sparsifier, FedAdam-Top carries out in a different fashion from the standard FedAdam as follows:

  1. 1.

    Let Δ​𝑴nt=𝒎nL,t−𝑴tΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑛𝐿𝑡superscript𝑴𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}=\boldsymbol{m}_{n}^{L,t}-\boldsymbol{M}^{t}, Δ​𝑽nt=𝒗nL,t−𝑽tΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑛𝐿𝑡superscript𝑽𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}=\boldsymbol{v}_{n}^{L,t}-\boldsymbol{V}^{t}, and Δ​𝑾nt=𝒘nL,t−𝑾tΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝐿𝑡superscript𝑾𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}=\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{L,t}-\boldsymbol{W}^{t} denote the updates of local moment estimates and model parameters.   2. 2.

    The centralized server reconstructs the sparse vectors Δ​𝑴^ntΔsuperscriptsubscript^𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑽^ntΔsuperscriptsubscript^𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}_{n}^{t}, and Δ​𝑾^ntΔsuperscriptsubscript^𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}_{n}^{t} using the received sparse masks and values of the non-zero elements, and computes the updates of global moment estimates and model parameters as Δ​𝑴^t=∑n=1N|𝒟~n|​Δ​𝑴^nt∑n=1N|𝒟~n|Δsuperscript^𝑴𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝑴𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}^{t}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}_{n}^{t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|}, Δ​𝑽^t=∑n=1N|𝒟~n|​Δ​𝑽^nt∑n=1N|𝒟~n|Δsuperscript^𝑽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝑽𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}^{t}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}_{n}^{t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|}, and Δ​𝑾^t=∑n=1N|𝒟~n|​Δ​𝑾^nt∑n=1N|𝒟~n|Δsuperscript^𝑾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝑾𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript~𝒟𝑛\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}=\frac{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}_{n}^{t}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\tilde{\mathcal{D}}_{n}|}. Afterwards, the centralized server transmits the updates of global moment estimates and model parameters Δ​𝑴^tΔsuperscript^𝑴𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}^{t}, Δ​𝑽^tΔsuperscript^𝑽𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}^{t}, and Δ​𝑾^tΔsuperscript^𝑾𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t} to each device.

  3. 3.

    Upon receiving Δ​𝑴^tΔsuperscript^𝑴𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}^{t}, Δ​𝑽^tΔsuperscript^𝑽𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}^{t}, and Δ​𝑾^tΔsuperscript^𝑾𝑡\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}, each device updates the global moment estimates and model parameters as follows: 𝑴t+1=𝑴t+Δ​𝑴^tsuperscript𝑴𝑡1superscript𝑴𝑡Δsuperscript^𝑴𝑡\boldsymbol{M}^{t+1}=\boldsymbol{M}^{t}+\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}^{t}, 𝑽t+1=𝑽t+Δ​𝑽^tsuperscript𝑽𝑡1superscript𝑽𝑡Δsuperscript^𝑽𝑡\boldsymbol{V}^{t+1}=\boldsymbol{V}^{t}+\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}^{t}, and 𝑾t+1=𝑾t+Δ​𝑾^tsuperscript𝑾𝑡1superscript𝑾𝑡Δsuperscript^𝑾𝑡\boldsymbol{W}^{t+1}=\boldsymbol{W}^{t}+\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}^{t}.

It can be seen that by separately sparsifying the updates of local moment estimates and model parameters Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}, and Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t} with the top-k𝑘k sparsifier, distributed devices in FedAdam-Top transmit the values of the top k𝑘k largest elements of the vectors and the top-k𝑘k sparse masks to the centralized server instead of the raw vectors. Let q𝑞q denote the floating-point precision. The total number of bits for uplink data transmission per communication round in FedAdam-Top is 3​N​(k​q+d)3𝑁𝑘𝑞𝑑3N(kq+d). Note that the total number of bits for uplink data transmission per communication round in the standard FedAdam is 3​N​d​q3𝑁𝑑𝑞3Ndq. Therefore, the uplink data transmission volume per communication round can be reduced from 𝒪​(3​d​q)𝒪3𝑑𝑞\mathcal{O}(3dq) in the standard FedAdam to 𝒪​(3​k​q+3​d)𝒪3𝑘𝑞3𝑑\mathcal{O}(3kq+3d) in FedAdam-Top.

To further reduce the communication overhead, we propose to improve the FedAdam-Top algorithm by sparsifying the updates of local moment estimates and model parameters with an SSM. Denote the SSM by 𝟙SSMntsubscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}. Notably, 𝟙SSMnt∈{0,1}dsubscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡superscript01𝑑\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}\in\{0,1\}^{d} is a binary vector with exactly k𝑘k ones and d−k𝑑𝑘d-k zeros. As shown in Algorithm 2, the proposed FedAdam-SSM algorithm sparsifies the updates Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}, and Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t} as follows:

Δ​𝑴^nt=Δ​𝑴nt⊙𝟙SSMnt,Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝑴𝑛𝑡direct-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{M}}_{n}^{t}=\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}\odot\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}, (10)
Δ​𝑽^nt=Δ​𝑽nt⊙𝟙SSMnt,Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝑽𝑛𝑡direct-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{V}}_{n}^{t}=\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}\odot\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}, (11)
Δ​𝑾^nt=Δ​𝑾nt⊙𝟙SSMnt.Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝑾𝑛𝑡direct-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\Delta\hat{\boldsymbol{W}}_{n}^{t}=\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}\odot\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}. (12)

As such, each device in FedAdam-SSM transmits a total of 444 vectors to the centralized server, which includes an SSM 𝟙SSMntsubscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}, and 333 k𝑘k-dimensional vectors containing the values of the non-zero elements of the sparse updates of local moment estimates and model parameters. The total number of bits for uplink data transmission per communication round in FedAdam-SSM is N​(3​k​q+d)𝑁3𝑘𝑞𝑑N\left(3kq+d\right). Therefore, the uplink data transmission volume per communication round can be further reduced from 𝒪​(3​k​q+3​d)𝒪3𝑘𝑞3𝑑\mathcal{O}(3kq+3d) in FedAdam-Top to 𝒪​(3​k​q+d)𝒪3𝑘𝑞𝑑\mathcal{O}(3kq+d) in FedAdam-SSM.

V Design of A Shared Sparse Mask

In this section, we optimize the SSM to mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by the sparsification error. We firstly derive an upper bound on the divergence between the local model trained by FedAdam-SSM and the desired model trained by centralized Adam. The divergence bound is related to the sparsification errors of the local model updates and moment estimates and the imbalanced data distribution. To mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by sparsification error, the main idea of designing the SSM is to minimize the divergence bound between FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam.

V-A Learning Performance Bound with Sparsification Error and Data Imbalance

Before the theoretical analysis, we make the following assumptions on the objective loss function.

Assumption 1

(Lipschitz continuous gradient). The loss function f​(𝐰,𝒟n)𝑓𝐰subscript𝒟𝑛f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n}) is differentiable and ∇f​(𝐰,𝒟n)∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝒟𝑛\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n}) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz continuous, i.e., for any n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, and 𝐱𝐱\boldsymbol{x}, 𝐲∈ℝd𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, ∥∇f(𝐱,𝒟n)\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x},\mathcal{D}_{n}) −∇f(𝐲,𝒟n)∥≤ρ∥𝐱−𝐲∥-\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y},\mathcal{D}_{n})\|\leq\rho\left\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}\right\|.

Assumption 2

(Bounded gradient). The loss function f​(𝐰,ξ)𝑓𝐰𝜉f(\boldsymbol{w},\xi) has G𝐺G-bounded gradient, i.e., for any 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, ξ∈∪𝒟n𝜉subscript𝒟𝑛\xi\in\cup\mathcal{D}_{n}, and j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d], we have |[∇f​(𝐰,ξ)]j|≤Gsubscriptdelimited-[]∇𝑓𝐰𝜉𝑗𝐺\left|\left[\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\xi)\right]_{j}\right|\leq G.

Assumption 3

(Bounded local and global variances). For any n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}, ξ∈𝒟n𝜉subscript𝒟𝑛\xi\in\mathcal{D}_{n}, and 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the stochastic gradient ∇f​(𝐰,ξ)∇𝑓𝐰𝜉\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\xi) has bounded variance, i.e., 𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐰,ξ)−∇f​(𝐰,𝒟n)‖2]≤σl2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝐰𝜉∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝒟𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\xi)-\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n})\right\|^{2}\right]\leq\sigma_{l}^{2}. We also assume that the variance of gradient ∇f​(𝐰,𝒟n)∇𝑓𝐰subscript𝒟𝑛\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n}) is bounded, i.e., ∥∇f(𝐰,𝒟n)\left\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\mathcal{D}_{n})\right. −∇f(𝐰,∪𝒟n)∥2≤σg2\left.-\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\cup\mathcal{D}_{n})\right\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{g}^{2}.

Note that Assumption 1 on bounded smoothness and Assumption 2 on bounded gradient are widely used in the FL community for convergence analysis[27, 28, 29, 19, 33]. In Assumption 3, the bounded variances of local and global gradients quantify the sampling noise and data distribution diversity among distributed devices in FL, respectively.

Remark 1

From Theorem 1, we can observe that the upper bound on ‖𝐰nl,t−𝐰ˇl,t‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑙𝑡superscriptˇ𝐰𝑙𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t}-\check{\boldsymbol{w}}^{l,t}\right\| is dominated by the term ΦΦ\Phi and the weighted sum of ‖𝐖t−𝐖t˘‖normsuperscript𝐖𝑡˘superscript𝐖𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{W}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{W}^{t}}\right\|, ‖𝐌t−𝐌t˘‖normsuperscript𝐌𝑡˘superscript𝐌𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{M}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{M}^{t}}\right\| and ‖𝐕t−𝐕t˘‖normsuperscript𝐕𝑡˘superscript𝐕𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{V}^{t}}\right\| as follows:

  1. 1.

    The term ΦΦ\Phi is determined by the variances of local and global gradient (i.e., σlD~nsubscript𝜎𝑙subscript~𝐷𝑛\frac{\sigma_{l}}{\sqrt{\tilde{D}_{n}}} and σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g}). Decreases in local and global gradient variances can contribute to a smaller divergence between the model parameters trained by FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam, which indicates an improved learning performance in FedAdam-SSM training. This is consistent with the fact that FL performs better on IID datasets than non-IID datasets.

  2. 2.

    The weighted sum term reveals the impact of the sparsification of the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates on the learning performance of FedAdam-SSM. Specifically, lower sparsification errors of model parameters and moment estimates, i.e., ‖𝑾t−𝑾t˘‖normsuperscript𝑾𝑡˘superscript𝑾𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{W}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{W}^{t}}\right\|, ‖𝑴t−𝑴t˘‖normsuperscript𝑴𝑡˘superscript𝑴𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{M}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{M}^{t}}\right\|, and ‖𝑽t−𝑽t˘‖normsuperscript𝑽𝑡˘superscript𝑽𝑡\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{V}^{t}}\right\|, can lead to a reduced gap between 𝒘nl,tsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t} and 𝒘ˇl,tsuperscriptˇ𝒘𝑙𝑡\check{\boldsymbol{w}}^{l,t}, and thereby improving the learning performance of FedAdam-SSM. Given zero sparsification errors (i.e., ‖𝑾t−𝑾t˘‖=0normsuperscript𝑾𝑡˘superscript𝑾𝑡0\left\|\boldsymbol{W}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{W}^{t}}\right\|=0, ‖𝑴t−𝑴t˘‖=0normsuperscript𝑴𝑡˘superscript𝑴𝑡0\left\|\boldsymbol{M}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{M}^{t}}\right\|=0, and ‖𝑽t−𝑽t˘‖=0normsuperscript𝑽𝑡˘superscript𝑽𝑡0\left\|\boldsymbol{V}^{t}-\breve{\boldsymbol{V}^{t}}\right\|=0), the divergence between FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam is reduced to the divergence between standard FedAdam and centralized Adam, i.e.,

    ‖𝒘nl,t−𝒘ˇl,t‖≤Φ,normsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑙𝑡superscriptˇ𝒘𝑙𝑡Φ\displaystyle\left\|\boldsymbol{w}_{n}^{l,t}-\check{\boldsymbol{w}}^{l,t}\right\|\leq\Phi, (24)

    which is exclusively related to the data distribution among the distributed devices.

Remark 2

Theorem 1 also shows that for the same sparsification ratio, FedAdam-Top can achieve the lowest weighted sum of the sparsification errors by separately sparsifying the local updates Δ​𝐖ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝐖nt\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝐌ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝐌nt\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}, and Δ​𝐕ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝐕nt\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t} with the top-kkk sparsifier. This indicates that the divergence between FedAdam-Top and centralized Adam serves as a lower bound on the divergence between sparse FedAdam and centralized Adam.

V-B Optimal Shared Sparse Mask

From Theorem 1, the main idea of minimizing the divergence between the model parameters trained by FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam is to minimize the weighted sum of the sparsification errors, i.e.,

Γ​‖Δ​𝑾nt⊙(1−𝟙SSMnt)‖+Λ​‖Δ​𝑴nt⊙(1−𝟙SSMnt)‖Γnormdirect-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡1subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡Λnormdirect-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡1subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\Gamma\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}\odot\left(1-\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}\right)\right\|+\Lambda\Big{\|}\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}\odot\left(1-\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}\right)\Big{\|}
+Θ​‖Δ​𝑽nt⊙(1−𝟙SSMnt)‖.Θnormdirect-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡1subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\displaystyle+\Theta\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}\odot\left(1-\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}\right)\right\|.\!\!\!\! (25)

To this end, we next proceed to find an optimal SSM by comparing the magnitude of ΓΓ\Gamma, ΛΛ\Lambda and ΘΘ\Theta as follows.

Proposition 1

If the exponential decay rate β2subscript𝛽2\beta_{2} satisfies

β2<1−11+2​G​ρ​d,subscript𝛽21112𝐺𝜌𝑑\displaystyle\beta_{2}<1-\frac{1}{1+2G\rho\sqrt{d}}, (26)

then

Γ>Θ>Λ.ΓΘΛ\displaystyle\Gamma>\Theta>\Lambda. (27)
Proof:

See the proof in Section II in the supplementary material. ∎

Remark 3

Notably, ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 is the Lipschitz constant, d>0𝑑0d>0 is the number of model parameters, β2∈[0,1)subscript𝛽201\beta_{2}\in[0,1) is the exponential decay rate of the second moment estimate, and G>0𝐺0G>0 is the upper bound on the stochastic gradient |[∇f​(𝐰,ξ)]j|subscriptdelimited-[]∇𝑓𝐰𝜉𝑗\left|\left[\nabla f(\boldsymbol{w},\xi)\right]_{j}\right|. Given that d𝑑d is typically an extremely large value, 1−11+2​G​ρ​d1112𝐺𝜌𝑑1-\frac{1}{1+2G\rho\sqrt{d}} approaches 111. Therefore, the inequality in (26) can be easily implemented since β2∈[0,1)subscript𝛽201\beta_{2}\in[0,1) is often set to 0.9990.9990.999 in the Adam optimizer.

From the theoretical and experimental analysis of model parameters and moment estimates produced by Adam[30, 34, 35], Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t} is of a much larger order of magnitude than Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}. Together with Proposition 1, it can be inferred that the term Γ​‖Δ​𝑾nt⊙(1−𝟙SSMnt)‖Γnormdirect-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡1subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\Gamma\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}\odot\left(1-\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}\right)\right\| is the major contributor to the divergence between FedAdam-SSM and centralized Adam. Therefore, the minimization of the weighted sum of the sparsification errors in (V-B) can be equivalently transformed into the minimization of ‖Δ​𝑾nt⊙(1−𝟙SSMnt)‖normdirect-productΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡1subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡\left\|\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}\odot\left(1-\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}\right)\right\|. As such, an optimal SSM can be determined by sparsifying the update of local model parameters with the top-k𝑘k sparsifier, i.e.,

𝟙SSMnt=𝟙Topk​(Δ​𝑾nt).subscript1superscriptsubscriptSSM𝑛𝑡subscript1subscriptTop𝑘Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\mathbbm{1}_{\text{SSM}_{n}^{t}}=\mathbbm{1}_{\text{Top}_{k}}\left(\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}\right). (28)

With this optimal SSM, the proposed FedAdam-SSM can effectively mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by the sparsification error.

VI Convergence Analysis

In this section, we analyze the convergence of the proposed FedAdam-SSM in both convex and non-convex settings.

We first present the convergence of FedAdam-SSM for general non-convex loss functions as follows.

Theorem 2

(Non-convexity). Suppose Assumptions 1, 2, and 3 hold. Then, after running FedAdam-SSM for T𝑇T communication rounds, we have

1T∑t=0T−1∥∇F(𝑾t)∥2≤2η​T(F(𝑾0)−F(𝑾T))+2((ηρ+2)(1−α)\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\!\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\!\left\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{W}^{t})\right\|^{2}\!\leq\!\frac{2}{\eta T}\left(F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{0}\right)\!-\!F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)\right)\!+\!2\left(\left(\eta\rho\!+\!2\right)\!(1\!-\!\alpha)\right.
+ηρ−1)η​G2​d​L2ϵ+6G2d((L−β2​(1−(β2)L)1−β2)G4​d​L4​ϵ3+L2ϵ\displaystyle\left.+\eta\rho-1\right)\frac{\eta G^{2}dL^{2}}{\epsilon}\!+\!6G^{2}d\Bigg{(}\!\left(L-\frac{\beta_{2}\left(1-(\beta_{2})^{L}\right)}{1-\beta_{2}}\right)\frac{G^{4}dL}{4\epsilon^{3}}+\frac{L^{2}}{\epsilon}
+4​β1​(1−(β1)L)ϵ​(1−β1)2+1+ρ2​L23​ϵ)+6∑n=1ND~n​(σlD~n+σg)2∑n=1ND~n.\displaystyle+\frac{4\beta_{1}\left(1-(\beta_{1})^{L}\right)}{\epsilon\left(1-\beta_{1}\right)^{2}}+1+\frac{\rho^{2}L^{2}}{3\epsilon}\Bigg{)}+6\!\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\frac{\tilde{D}_{n}\left(\frac{\sigma_{l}}{\sqrt{\tilde{D}_{n}}}+\sigma_{g}\right)^{2}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\tilde{D}_{n}}.\!\!\!\!\!\! (29)
Proof:

See the proof in Section III in the supplementary material. ∎

Remark 4

The convergence rate upper bound of FedAdam-SSM given in Theorem 2 includes a vanishing part as the sparsification ratio α𝛼\alpha increases and a constant part involving the local and global variances σlsubscript𝜎𝑙\sigma_{l} and σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g} caused by sampling noise and heterogeneous distributed datasets. This coincides with our intuitive understanding: 1) A lower sparsification ratio can contribute to a reduced sparsification error, and thereby an improved model performance. 2) Non-IID data distributions can result in a global model that produces shifted gradients on local datasets, leading to degraded model accuracy.

Proposition 2

Assume Assumptions 1, 2, and 3 hold, and let the learning rate η=𝒪​(1L2​T)𝜂𝒪1superscript𝐿2𝑇\eta=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{L^{2}\sqrt{T}}\right). Then, for FedAdam-SSM, it holds that

1T​∑t=0T−1‖∇F​(𝑾t)‖2≤𝒪​((F​(𝑾0)−F​(𝑾T))​L2T)1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝑾𝑡2𝒪𝐹superscript𝑾0𝐹superscript𝑾𝑇superscript𝐿2𝑇\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{W}^{t})\right\|^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\left(F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{0}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)\right)L^{2}}{\sqrt{T}}\right)
+𝒪​((1−α)​G2​dϵ​T)+𝒪​((1−α)​ρ​G2​dϵ​L2​T).𝒪1𝛼superscript𝐺2𝑑italic-ϵ𝑇𝒪1𝛼𝜌superscript𝐺2𝑑italic-ϵsuperscript𝐿2𝑇\displaystyle+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{(1-\alpha)G^{2}d}{\epsilon\sqrt{T}}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{(1-\alpha)\rho G^{2}d}{\epsilon L^{2}T}\right). (30)
Remark 5

From Proposition 2, we can see that when the communication round T𝑇T is sufficiently large, the dominant term of the asymptotic convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM achieves a linear speedup of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right). This indicates that to reach any error δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, the FedAdam-SSM algorithm needs 𝒪​(1δ2)𝒪1superscript𝛿2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\delta^{2}}\right) communication rounds on non-convex loss functions.

Remark 6

From Proposition 2, it can be seen that when L<((1−α)​ρ​G2​dϵ​(F​(𝐖0)−F​(𝐖T))​T)14𝐿superscript1𝛼𝜌superscript𝐺2𝑑italic-ϵ𝐹superscript𝐖0𝐹superscript𝐖𝑇𝑇14L<\left(\frac{(1-\alpha)\rho G^{2}d}{\epsilon\left(F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{0}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)\right)\sqrt{T}}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}, the term 𝒪​((1−α)​ρ​G2​dϵ​L2​T)𝒪1𝛼𝜌superscript𝐺2𝑑italic-ϵsuperscript𝐿2𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{(1-\alpha)\rho G^{2}d}{\epsilon L^{2}T}\right) dominates the given bound on convergence of FedAdam-SSM, which indicates that the convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM can be improved by increasing local epoch L𝐿L. This phenomenon is consistent with our intuitive understanding that using a large local epoch L𝐿L can lead to a local minimizer and thereby speed up the training process of FedAdam-SSM. However, there is a point where increasing local epoch L𝐿L too much can degrade the model accuracy and consequently slow down the convergence rate. When L>((1−α)​ρ​G2​dϵ​(F​(𝐖0)−F​(𝐖T))​T)14𝐿superscript1𝛼𝜌superscript𝐺2𝑑italic-ϵ𝐹superscript𝐖0𝐹superscript𝐖𝑇𝑇14L>\left(\frac{(1-\alpha)\rho G^{2}d}{\epsilon\left(F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{0}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)\right)\sqrt{T}}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}, the dominant term becomes 𝒪​((F​(𝐖0)−F​(𝐖T))​L2T)𝒪𝐹superscript𝐖0𝐹superscript𝐖𝑇superscript𝐿2𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\left(F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{0}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)\right)L^{2}}{\sqrt{T}}\right). In this case, a large local epoch L𝐿L can lead to a strong device drift, which degrades the training performance of FedAdam-SSM. The above discussion provides guidance for selecting an appropriate value of L𝐿L to speed up the convergence rate.

In the following, we present the convergence of FedAdam-SSM under the Polyak-Łitalic-Ł\Lojasiewicz (PŁitalic-Ł\L) condition.

Assumption 4

(PŁitalic-Ł\L condition). The objective loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\boldsymbol{w}) satisfies a PŁitalic-Ł\L-μ𝜇\mu inequality, i.e., ‖∇F​(𝐰)‖2superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝐰2\left\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{w})\right\|^{2} ≥2​μ​(F​(𝐰)−F​(𝐰∗))absent2𝜇𝐹𝐰𝐹superscript𝐰\geq 2\mu\left(F(\boldsymbol{w})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\right), ∀𝐰∈ℝdfor-all𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\forall\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Theorem 3

(PŁitalic-Ł\L condition). Suppose Assumptions 1, 2, 3, and 4 hold. Then, after running FedAdam-SSM for T𝑇T communication rounds, we have

F​(𝑾T)−F​(𝒘∗)≤(1−η​μ)T​(F​(𝑾0)−F​(𝒘∗))+η​G2​d​L2μ​ϵ𝐹superscript𝑾𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘superscript1𝜂𝜇𝑇𝐹superscript𝑾0𝐹superscript𝒘𝜂superscript𝐺2𝑑superscript𝐿2𝜇italic-ϵ\displaystyle F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{T}\left(F(\boldsymbol{W}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\right)+\frac{\eta G^{2}dL^{2}}{\mu\epsilon}
((ηρ+2)(1−α)+ηρ−1)+3​G2​dμ(4​β1​(1−(β1)L)ϵ​(1−β1)2+L2ϵ+ρ2​L23​ϵ\displaystyle((\eta\rho\!+\!2)(1\!-\!\alpha)\!+\!\eta\rho\!-\!1)\!+\!\frac{3G^{2}d}{\mu}\left(\frac{4\beta_{1}\left(1\!-\!(\beta_{1})^{L}\right)}{\epsilon\left(1\!-\!\beta_{1}\right)^{2}}\!+\!\frac{L^{2}}{\epsilon}\!+\!\frac{\rho^{2}L^{2}}{3\epsilon}\right.
+1+G4​d​L4​ϵ3(L−β2​(1−(β2)L)1−β2))+3μ∑n=1ND~n​(σlD~n+σg)2∑n=1ND~n.\displaystyle\left.+1\!+\!\frac{G^{4}dL}{4\epsilon^{3}}\Bigg{(}L\!-\!\frac{\beta_{2}\left(1\!-\!(\beta_{2})^{L}\right)}{1\!-\!\beta_{2}}\Bigg{)}\right)+\frac{3}{\mu}\!\sum_{n=1}^{N}\!\frac{\tilde{D}_{n}\!\left(\!\frac{\sigma_{l}}{\sqrt{\tilde{D}_{n}}}\!+\!\sigma_{g}\!\right)^{2}}{\sum_{n=1}^{N}\tilde{D}_{n}}.\!\!\!\!\! (31)

See the proof in Section IV in the supplementary material. ∎

Remark 7

From Theorem 3, it can be inferred that, under the PŁitalic-Ł\L condition, a small learning rate can slow down the convergence speed, while a large learning rate can compromise the model accuracy. Specifically, a small learning rate η𝜂\eta can result in a slow decay of the term (1−η​μ)T​(F​(𝐖0)−F​(𝐰∗))superscript1𝜂𝜇𝑇𝐹superscript𝐖0𝐹superscript𝐰\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{T}\left(F(\boldsymbol{W}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\right), thereby yielding a deceleration of the training process. On the other hand, using a large learning rate η𝜂\eta can contribute to an increased term ((η​ρ+2)​(1−α)+η​ρ−1)​η​G2​d​L2μ​ϵ𝜂𝜌21𝛼𝜂𝜌1𝜂superscript𝐺2𝑑superscript𝐿2𝜇italic-ϵ\frac{\left((\eta\rho+2)(1-\alpha)+\eta\rho-1\right)\eta G^{2}dL^{2}}{\mu\epsilon}, thereby leading to degraded model accuracy. This is consistent with our intuitive understanding that a small η𝜂\eta can cause the optimizer to converge slowly, while a large η𝜂\eta can cause drastic updates which can lead to divergent behaviour.

Proposition 3

Suppose Assumptions 1, 2, 3, and 4 hold, and let the learning rate η=𝒪​(ln⁡TL2​T)𝜂𝒪𝑇superscript𝐿2𝑇\eta=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\ln T}{L^{2}T}\right). After running the FedAdam-SSM algorithm, it holds that that

F​(𝑾T)−F​(𝒘∗)≤𝒪~​(F​(𝑾0)−F​(𝒘∗)T)𝐹superscript𝑾𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘~𝒪𝐹superscript𝑾0𝐹superscript𝒘𝑇\displaystyle F\left(\boldsymbol{W}^{T}\right)-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{F(\boldsymbol{W}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})}{T}\right)
+𝒪~​(((2−α))​ρ​G2​dμ​ϵ​L2​T2)+𝒪~​((1−α)​G2​dμ​ϵ​T).~𝒪2𝛼𝜌superscript𝐺2𝑑𝜇italic-ϵsuperscript𝐿2superscript𝑇2~𝒪1𝛼superscript𝐺2𝑑𝜇italic-ϵ𝑇\displaystyle+\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\left((2-\alpha)\right)\frac{\rho G^{2}d}{\mu\epsilon L^{2}T^{2}}\right)+\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left((1-\alpha)\frac{G^{2}d}{\mu\epsilon T}\right). (32)
Proof:

See the proof in Section V in the supplemental material. ∎

Remark 8

From Proposition 3, we can observe that under the PŁitalic-Ł\L condition, the convergence rate of the FedAdam-SSM algorithm can be improved to 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}\right) by setting η=𝒪​(ln⁡TL2​T)𝜂𝒪𝑇superscript𝐿2𝑇\eta=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\ln T}{L^{2}T}\right). That is, under the PŁitalic-Ł\L condition, FedAdam-SSM only requires 𝒪​(1δ)𝒪1𝛿\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right) communication rounds to reach an error δ>0𝛿0\delta>0.

VII Experimental Results

VII-A Experimental Settings

To evaluate the FL performance of the proposed FedAdam-SSM algorithm, we train a CNN on the Fashion-MNIST dataset, VGG-11 on the CIFAR-10 dataset, and ResNet-18 on the SVHN dataset with IID and non-IID settings to demonstrate the training efficiency.

Datasets and models. 1) Fashion-MNIST consists of a training set of 600006000060000 28×28282828\times 28 grayscale images belonging to 101010 different classes, and a test set of 100001000010000 images. 2) CIFAR-10 consists of 600006000060000 32×32323232\times 32 RGB images in 101010 classes (from 00 to 999), with 500050005000 training images and 100010001000 test images per class. 3) SVHN contains over 600006000060000 32×32323232\times 32 RGB images in 101010 classes (from 00 to 999), which is cropped from real-world pictures of house number plates. For the Fashion-MNIST dataset, we adopt a CNN model with two 5×5555\times 5 convolutional layers (each followed by ReLU activation and a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer), two fully connected layers, and a final softmax output layer. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we adopt a VGG-11 model that consists of eight 3×3333\times 3 convolutional layers, three fully connected layers, and a final softmax output layer. For the SVHN dataset, we adopt a ResNet-18 model that consists of a 2×2222\times 2 convolutional layer, two pooling layers, eight residual units (each with two 3×3333\times 3 convolutional layers), a fully connected layer, and a final softmax output layer.

Data distribution. For non-IID settings, we follow the previous works [36, 37] to split the local datasets using the Dirichlet distribution with a concentration parameter θ=0.1𝜃0.1\theta=0.1. Note that the lower the concentration parameter, the higher the non-IID degree of the data distribution.

Implementation. In our experiments, we set the number of distributed devices N=20𝑁20N=20, local epoch L=30𝐿30L=30, learning rate η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001, and sparsification ratio α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05. For the Adam optimizer, we set β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9, β2=0.999subscript𝛽20.999\beta_{2}=0.999, and ϵ=10−6italic-ϵsuperscript106\epsilon=10^{-6}. As previously stated, FedAdam-SSM uploads the SSM to the centralized server to represent the position of each non-zero element in the sparse vectors. Alternatively, we could upload the indices of these non-zero elements to represent their positions instead of uploading the SSM. This method necessitates log2⁡(d)subscript2𝑑\log_{2}(d) bits to inform the centralized server of the index of each non-zero element within the d𝑑d-dimensional sparse vector[38, 39]. In our experiment, we employ both methods and select the one with the lower communication overhead. Therefore, the total number of bits for uplink data transmission per communication round in FedAdam-SSM and FedAdam-Top is min⁡{N​(3​k​q+d),N​k​(3​q+log2⁡(d))}𝑁3𝑘𝑞𝑑𝑁𝑘3𝑞subscript2𝑑\min\{N(3kq+d),Nk\left(3q+\log_{2}(d)\right)\} and min⁡{3​N​(k​q+d),3​N​k​(q+log2⁡(d))}3𝑁𝑘𝑞𝑑3𝑁𝑘𝑞subscript2𝑑\min\{3N(kq+d),3Nk\left(q+\log_{2}(d)\right)\}, respectively.

Baselines. For comparison purpose, we consider the following baseline algorithms: 1) FedAdam (See Algorithm 1), 2) FedAdam-Top, 3) 1-bit Adam[29], 4) Efficient Adam[28], 5) Fairness-top[40], 6) FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, and 6) FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}. FedAdam is in fact a special case of FedAdam-SSM and FedAdam-Top when we set the sparsification ratio α𝛼\alpha to 111. 1-bit Adam follows a two-stage training paradigm: a) first run vanilla Adam as a warm-up, where the local moment estimates and model parameters are communicated with full precision; b) then fix the second moment estimate as a precondition and communicate the first moment estimates with error-compensated 1-bit quantization. Efficient Adam utilizes a two-way quantization scheme to reduce the communication overhead and a two-way error feedback strategy to compensate for quantization errors. Fairness-top, FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M} and FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V} employ an SSM to sparsify the local moment estimates and model parameters, thereby reducing the uplink communication overhead. In Fairness-top, the SSM is determined by sparsifying the union of the local moment estimates and model parameters with the top-k𝑘k sparsifier. FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M} and FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V} determine the SSM by sparsifying the local first moment estimates and the second moment estimates with the top-k𝑘k sparsifier, respectively.

VII-B Results and Discussion

VII-B1 Comparison of Values of Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}

To demonstrate the magnitude of the update of model parameters and moment estimates (i.e., Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}, and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}), Fig. 1 compares the probability density of their logarithmic values on different datasets and models. From Fig. 1, we can observe that the logarithms of Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t} appear to approximately follow normal distributions with different means and variances, and the logarithmic values indicate that Δ​𝑾nt>Δ​𝑴nt>Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}>\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t}>\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}. Specifically, for CNN on Fashion-MNIST, Fig. 1 (a) shows that the logarithms of Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t} exhibit approximate normal distributions centered around −22-2, −33-3 and −66-6, respectively. For ResNet-18 on SVHN, Fig. 1 (b) indicates that the logarithms of Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t} fall within their respective ranges of −7.57.5-7.5 to −44-4, −12.512.5-12.5 to −88-8, and −2020-20 to −1515-15, respectively. For VGG-11 on CIFAR-10, Fig. 1 (c) illustrates that the logarithms of Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}, Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t} lie in the ranges of −1010-10 to −55-5, −2525-25 to −1010-10, and −3535-35 to −2020-20, respectively. Therefore, the experimental results verify that the update of model parameters (i.e., Δ​𝑾ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{W}_{n}^{t}) is significantly larger in magnitude compared to the updates of moment estimates (i.e., Δ​𝑴ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑴𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{M}_{n}^{t} and Δ​𝑽ntΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑽𝑛𝑡\Delta\boldsymbol{V}_{n}^{t}), which is also consistent with the theoretical and experimental analysis of model parameters and moment estimates produced by Adam[30, 34, 35].

VII-B2 Performance Comparison with Baseline Algorithms

Fig. 2 compares the model accuracy versus communication overhead between FedAdam-SSM and baseline algorithms. For CNN on Fashion-MNIST, the improvement in test accuracy compared to FedAdam-Top, Fairness-Top, FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, FedAdam, 1-bit Adam and Efficient Adam is approximately 1.3%, 2.9%, 8.2%, 10.9%, 3.7%, 14.4%, 21.8% in the IID setting, and 1.8%, 2.5%, 9.7%, 10.7%, 11.7%, 17.3%, 39.3% in the Non-IID setting. For ResNet on SVHN, the improvement in test accuracy compared to FedAdam-Top, Fairness-Top, FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, FedAdam, 1-bit Adam and Efficient Adam is approximately 4.5%, 1.1%, 9.6%, 1.9%, 2.3%, 22%, 23.1% in the IID setting, and 4.3%, 2.9%, 10.7%, 5.1%, 6.4%, 20.2%, 24.9% in the Non-IID setting. For VGG-11 on CIFAR-10, the improvement in test accuracy compared to FedAdam-Top, Fairness-Top, FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, FedAdam, 1-bit Adam and Efficient Adam is approximately 4.1%, 1.5%, 3.8%, 10.7%, 4.8%, 15.2%, 14.4% in the IID setting, and 2.7%, 5.9%, 6.1%, 18.4%, 5.9%, 36.5%, 39.6% in the Non-IID setting. Table I compares the convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM and baseline algorithms.

From Fig. 2 and Table I, we can observe that in the context of both IID and Non-IID data distribution settings, FedAdam-SSM outperforms baseline algorithms both on model accuracy and convergence rate. The observations are listed as follows. First, FedAdam-SSM outperforms its counterparts among the sparse FedAdam algorithms both on test accuracy and convergence rate, including FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, and Fairness-top. The improvement in test accuracy is approximately 3.8% ∼similar-to\sim 10.9% compared to FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, 1.9% ∼similar-to\sim 18.4% compared to FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, and 1.3% ∼similar-to\sim 4.5% compared to FedAdam-Top on different models and datasets. Additionally, FedAdam-SSM achieves approximately over 2.19×\times convergence rate improvements over FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, over 2.77×\times convergence rate improvements over FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, and over 1.1×\times convergence rate improvements over FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}. Notably, FedAdam-SSM, FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, and Fairness-top employ different SSMs to introduce sparsity in the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates, and maintain an identical communication overhead of 𝒪​(3​k​q+d)𝒪3𝑘𝑞𝑑\mathcal{O}(3kq+d). This observation highlights that the proposed SSM outperforms the alternative SSMs in terms of model accuracy and convergence rate. This is because our proposed SSM minimizes the divergence between centralized Adam and sparse FedAdam, which is consistent with Theorem 1. With the same sparsification ratio as FedAdam-SSMMsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑀\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{M}, FedAdam-SSMVsubscriptFedAdam-SSM𝑉\text{FedAdam-SSM}_{V}, and Fairness-top, the proposed SSM effectively reduces the sparsification error, thereby improving both model accuracy and convergence rate.

Second, it can be observed that FedAdam-SSM prevails slightly over FedAdam-Top and Fairness-Top in terms of test accuracy and convergence rate. Furthermore, FedAdam-SSM requires a significantly lower computational complexity compared to FedAdam-Top and Fairness-Top. To be specific, FedAdam-SSM improves test accuracy approximately 1.3% ∼similar-to\sim 4.5% compared to FedAdam-Top and 1.1% ∼similar-to\sim 2.9% compared to Fairness-Top on different models and datasets. The improvement in convergence rate is approximately 1.37×⁣∼similar-to\times\sim 5.59×\times over FedAdam-Top, and 1.10×⁣∼similar-to\times\sim 2.74×\times over Fairness-Top. Note that FedAdam-SSM determines the SSM by applying top-k𝑘k sparsification to local model parameters. In contrast, Fairness-top determines the SSM by sparsifying the union of local model parameters and moment estimates with the top-k𝑘k sparsifier. FedAdam-Top separately sparsifies the local model parameters and moment estimates using the top-k𝑘k sparsification method. Therefore, the computational complexity of FedAdam-SSM, FedAdam-Top, and Fairness-Top can be represented as 𝒪​(d​log⁡(k))𝒪𝑑𝑘\mathcal{O}\left(d\log(k)\right), 𝒪​(3​d​log⁡(k))𝒪3𝑑𝑘\mathcal{O}\left(3d\log(k)\right), and 𝒪​(9​d​k)𝒪9𝑑𝑘\mathcal{O}\left(9dk\right), respectively. FedAdam-SSM reduces the computational complexity by over 66.6% compared to both FedAdam-Top and Fairness-Top.

Third, we can observe that FedAdam-SSM significantly outperforms the quantized FedAdam algorithms, i.e., 1-bit Adam and Efficient Adam, in terms of test accuracy and convergence rate. Specifically, the improvement in test accuracy is approximately 15.2% ∼similar-to\sim 36.5% compared to 1-bit Adam, and 14.5% ∼similar-to\sim 39.6% compared to Efficient Adam on different models and datasets. In addition, we can see that compared to the Non-IID setting, FedAdam-SSM achieves higher test accuracy and faster convergence rate in the IID data distribution setting. This is due to the fact that non-IID data distributions can result in a global model that produces shifted gradients on local datasets, and thereby a degraded model accuracy. This observation is consistent with Theorem 2 that lower local and global variances σlsubscript𝜎𝑙\sigma_{l} and σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g} can lead to improved training performance.

VII-B3 Sensitivity to Hyperparameters

Local epoch measures the progress of local gradient descent. Fig. 3 plots the test accuracy of FedAdam-SSM for different values of local epoch L𝐿L. From Fig. 3, we can see that the convergence rate shows a decreasing trend as L𝐿L increases. Additionally, the test accuracy shows an initial increasing trend followed by a subsequent decrease as L𝐿L increases. This is due to the fact that increasing local epoch L𝐿L can lead to a local minimizer and thereby improve the convergence rate. On the other hand, increasing L𝐿L too much can lead to a strong device drift, which compromises the model accuracy and slows down the convergence. This observeation highlights a trade-off in selecting the appropriate value of L𝐿L to balance the convergence rate and model accuracy, which is consistent with Proposition 2.

Learning rate determines the step size in each gradient descent iteration while moving towards the minimum of the loss function. Fig. 4 plots the test accuracy of FedAdam-SSM for different learning rate η𝜂\eta on different models and datasets. We can observe that on the one hand, increasing the learning rate η𝜂\eta can improve the test accuracy and speed up the convergence. On the other hand, a too large η𝜂\eta compromises the model accuracy and consequently degrades the convergence rate. This is due to the fact that a small η𝜂\eta can cause the optimizer to converge slowly or get stuck in plateaus or undesirable local minima, while a large η𝜂\eta can cause drastic updates which can lead to divergent behaviour. The above discussion highlights a guidance for selecting an appropriate value of η𝜂\eta to optimize the training performance, which is consistent with Theorem 3.

Sparsification ratio measures the sparsification error in the training process. Fig. 5 plots the test accuracy of FedAdam-SSM for different sparsification ratio α𝛼\alpha on different models and datasets. It can be observed that increasing the learning rate η𝜂\eta can improve the test accuracy and speed up the convergence. This aligns with the findings of Theorem 2, demonstrating that a decreased sparsification ratio is associated with a diminished sparsification error, consequently leading to enhanced training performance.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a novel sparse FedAdam algorithm called FedAdam-SSM, which incorporates an SSM into the sparsification of the updates of local model parameters and moment estimates to reduce the uplink communication overhead. We have provided an upper bound on the divergence between the local model trained by FedAdam-SSM and the desired model trained by centralized Adam, which is related to the sparsification error and imbalanced data distribution. Based on this divergence bound, we have optimized the SSM to mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by the sparsification error. We have provided convergence bounds for the proposed FedAdam-SSM with both non-convex and convex objective function settings. We have investigated the impact of local epoch, learning rate and sparsification ratio on the convergence rate of FedAdam-SSM, and provided guidances for selecting appropriate values of local epoch, learning rate and sparsification ratio to improve the training performance. Extensive experiments on Fashion-MNIST, SVHN and CIFAR-10 datasets have verified the theoretical analysis and showed that FedAdam-SSM outperforms baselines in terms of both convergence rate and test accuracy. This work represents the first attempt to design the SSM for the sparsification of local model updates and moment estimates in sparse FedAdam and to provide a corresponding theoretical analysis.
